entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: mark_allen
entries.text: Mark has uploaded a developer release of Net::Amazon::EC2 to CPAN with support for AWS4 signatures. He's keen to get feedback from AWS users.
entries.title: Net::Amazon::EC2 now with v4 signature support

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: Dave compares Mojo::DOM and Web::Query for web scraping, and finds that the code he has to write is almost identical. Apparently Mojo::DOM was slightly faster.
entries.title: Mojo::DOM vs Web::Query

entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: brian shows the benefits of creating data-driven tests, and talks through some of the ways you might do this.
entries.title: Separate data and behavior with table-driven testing

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Yanick uses digiKam to manage his digital photos, and his wife has a digital photo frame. He takes us through the code he uses to get tagged photos from one to the other.
entries.title: From Digikam to a Digital Frame

entries.author: tom_legrady
entries.text: This is just one in a series of blog posts looking at Perl's performance math(s) operations.
entries.title: Better Performance Through Transposition

entries.author: dave_cross
entries.text: Dave gave a talk about the TwittElection site, which he created for the recent UK general election. He's posted his slides and notes from the talk.
entries.title: TwittElection at OpenTech

entries.author: andreas_huttel
entries.text: The Gentoo linux distribution is looking for volunteers to help test their Perl 5.22 package.
entries.title: Perl 5.22 testers needed

entries.author: joel_berger
entries.text: Joel's perspective on this year's YAPC::NA.
entries.title: YAPC::NA 2015 Wrap-up and More New (PSGI!) Modules

entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: An overview of hexadecimal floating point literals, which were introduced in 5.22, and some of the gotchas you need to be aware of.
entries.title: Perl v5.22 adds hexadecimal floating point literals

entries.text: Randal Schwartz is getting old (I know, this probably isn't news for most of us, but let's humour him, ok?); Ovid posted a tip for git stashers; Yanick has hacked on his script for creating cheatsheets.
entries.title: Quick Links

entries.author: larry_wall
entries.text: The Swiss Perl Workshop runs from Thursday 27th August to Saturday 29th August. A Perl 6 hackathon will run throughout, keynotes and talks are on the Friday, and Larry Wall will be there.
entries.title: Swiss Perl Workshop: The Programme

entries.text: Today is the last day to buy your YAPC::EU pass at the discounted price.
entries.title: YAPC::EU early-bird dead-line is today

entries.text: Microsoft, Apple, Google, and Mozilla have started working on a compiled code format for web browsers. Where languages currently compile down to Javascript, in the future they could compile down to WebAssembly. See also this post by Abel Avram
entries.title: WebAssembly

entries.text: A new resource for the javascript community, which includes a list of curated Javascript news.
entries.title: JavaScript.com

entries.author: nik_silver
entries.text: Nik explains how you can track progress against stories in Google sheets, and produce a burn-up chart.
entries.title: Make a burn-up chart in Google Sheets ... the easy way

entries.text: Not Perl, and not even in the last week, but I came across this today. What struck me is the line that Daniel "has spent at least 2 hours every day for the past 17 years working on and maintaining curl (~13k hours)". Read more about Daniel and cURL on his blog. Now that is dedication to an open-source project!
entries.title: 17 Years of curl With Daniel Stenberg
Caching data using the Cache module
DNS Name resolving - check DNS propagation with Perl
How to check if a server is live using Ping?

header:
Some weeks there are clear themes in the Perl-related blog posts,
such as just after a YAPC or major release. And then other weeks
are all over the place. That's a good thing, I think.

WebAssembly is probably of interest to many readers, as a possible
new compilation format for the web.

But my favourite entry this week is about Daniel Stenberg's
dedication to the cURL project: 17 years and still going strong!
subject: Randal Schwartz is getting old
